{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_bdrk_016e2Y9SshUQkD2tFuoXj1q9","type":"tool_result","content":"     1---\n     2layout: user-guide\n     3---\n     4\n     5Handling Matrix Layout Differences on Different Platforms\n     6=========================================================\n     7\n     8The differences between default matrix layout or storage conventions between GLSL (OpenGL/Vulkan) and HLSL has been an issue that frequently causes confusion among developers. When writing applications that work on different targets, one important goal that developers frequently seek is to make it possible to pass the same matrix generated by host code to the same shader code, regardless of what graphics API is being used (e.g. Vulkan, OpenGL or Direct3D). As a solution to shader cross-compilation, Slang provides necessary tools for developers to navigate around the differences between GLSL and HLSL targets.\n     9\n    10A high level summary:\n    11\n    12* Default matrix **layout** in memory for Slang is `row-major`. \n    13  * Except when running the compiler through the `slangc` tool, in which case the default is `col-major`. This default is for *legacy* reasons and may change in the future.\n    14* Row-major layout is the only *portable* layout to use across targets (with significant caveats for non 4x4 matrices)\n    15* Use `setMatrixLayoutMode`/`spSetMatrixLayoutMode`/`createSession` to set the default  \n    16* Use `-matrix-layout-row-major` or `-matrix-layout-column-major` for the command line \n    17  * or via `spProcessCommandLineArguments`/`processCommandLineArguments`\n    18* Depending on your host maths library, matrix sizes and targets, it may be necessary to convert matrices at host/kernel boundary  \n    19  \n    20On the portability issue, some targets *ignore* the matrix layout mode, notably CUDA and CPU/C++. For this reason for the widest breadth of targets it is recommended to use *row-major* matrix layout.\n    21\n    22Two conventions of matrix transform math\n    23----------------------------------------\n    24\n    25Depending on the platform a developer is used to, a matrix-vector transform can be expressed as either `v*m` (`mul(v, m)` in HLSL), or `m*v` (`mul(m,v)` in HLSL). This convention, together with the matrix layout (column-major or row-major), determines how a matrix should be filled out in host code. \n    26\n    27In HLSL/Slang the order of vector and matrix parameters to `mul` determine how the *vector* is interpreted. This interpretation is required because a vector does not in and of itself differentiate between being a row or a column.\n    28\n    29* `mul(v, m)` - v is interpreted as a row vector.\n    30* `mul(m, v)` - v is interpreted as a column vector.\n    31\n    32Through this mechanism a developer is able to write transforms in their preferred style. \n    33\n    34These two styles are not directly interchangeable - for a given `v` and `m` then generally `mul(v, m) != mul(m, v)`. For that the matrix needs to be transposed so\n    35\n    36* `mul(v, m) == mul(transpose(m), v)`\n    37* `mul(m, v) == mul(v, transpose(m))`\n    38\n    39This behavior is *independent* of how a matrix layout in memory. Host code needs to be aware of how a shader code will interpret a matrix stored in memory, it's layout, as well as the vector interpretation convention used in shader code (ie `mul(v,m)` or `mul(m, v)`).\n    40\n    41[Matrix layout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Row-_and_column-major_order) can be either `row-major` or `column-major`. The difference just determines which elements are contiguous in memory. `Row-major` means the rows elements are contiguous. `Column-major` means the column elements are contiguous.\n    42\n    43Another way to think about this difference is in terms of where translation terms should be placed in memory when filling a typical 4x4 transform matrix. When transforming a row vector (ie `mul(v, m)`) with a `row-major` matrix layout, translation will be at `m + 12, 13, 14`. For a `column-major` matrix layout, translation will be at `m + 3, 7, 11`.\n    44\n    45For simplicity's sake the remainder of this discussion assumes that the `mul(v, m)` equivalent in host code follows the interpretation that `v` is a *row* vector.\n    46\n    47Discussion\n    48----------\n    49\n    50There are four variables in play here:\n    51\n    52* Host vector interpretation (row or column) - and therefore effective transform order (column) `m * v` or (row) `v * m`\n    53* Host matrix memory layout\n    54* Shader vector interpretation (as determined via `mul(v, m)` or `mul(m, v)` )\n    55* Shader matrix memory layout \n    56\n    57Since each item can be either `row` or `column` there are 16 possible combinations. For simplicity let's reduce the variable space by making some assumptions.\n    58\n    591) The same vector convention will be used in host code as in shader code. \n    602) The host maths matrix layout is the same as the kernel.\n    61\n    62If we accept 1, then we can ignore the vector interpretation because as long as they are consistent then only matrix layout is significant.\n    63If we accept 2, then there are only two possible combinations - either both host and shader are using `row-major` matrix layout or `column-major` layout.\n    64\n    65This is simple, but is perhaps not the end of the story. First lets assume that we want our Slang code to be as portable as possible. As previously discussed for CUDA and C++/CPU targets Slang ignores the matrix layout settings - the matrix layout is *always* `row-major`.\n    66\n    67Second lets consider performance. The matrix layout in a host maths library is not arbitrary from a performance point of view. A performant host maths library will want to use SIMD instructions. With both x86/x64 SSE and ARM NEON SIMD it makes a performance difference which layout is used, depending on if `column` or `row` is the *preferred* vector interpretation. If the `row` vector interpretation is preferred, it is most performant to have `row-major` matrix layout. Conversely if `column` vector interpretation is preferred `column-major` matrix will be the most performant.\n    68\n    69The performance difference comes down to a SIMD implementation having to do a transpose if the layout doesn't match the preferred vector interpretation. \n    70\n    71If we put this all together - best performance, consistency between vector interpretation, and platform independence we get:\n    72\n    731) Consistency : Same vector interpretation in shader and host code\n    742) Platform independence: Kernel uses `row-major` matrix layout\n    753) Performance: Host vector interpretation should match host matrix layout\n    76\n    77The only combination that fulfills all aspects is `row-major` matrix layout and `row` vector interpretation for both host and kernel.\n    78\n    79It's worth noting that for targets that honor the default matrix layout - that setting can act like a toggle transposing a matrix layout. If for some reason the combination of choices leads to inconsistent vector transforms, an implementation can perform this transform in *host* code at the boundary between host and the kernel. This is not the most performant or convenient scenario, but if supported in an implementation it could be used for targets that do not support kernel matrix layout settings. \n    80\n    81If only targeting platforms that honor matrix layout, there is more flexibility, our constraints are\n    82\n    831) Consistency : Same vector interpretation in shader and host code\n    842) Performance: Host vector interpretation should match host matrix layout\n    85\n    86Then there are two combinations that work\n    87\n    881) `row-major` matrix layout for host and kernel, and `row` vector interpretation.\n    892) `column-major` matrix layout for host and kernel, and `column` vector interpretation.\n    90\n    91If the host maths library is not performance orientated, it may be arbitrary from a performance point of view if a `row` or `column` vector interpretation is used. In that case assuming shader and host vector interpretation is the same it is only important that the kernel and maths library matrix layout match.\n    92\n    93Another way of thinking about these combinations is to think of each change in `row-major`/`column-major` matrix layout and `row`/`column` vector interpretation is a transpose. If there are an *even* number of flips then all the transposes cancel out. Therefore the following combinations work\n    94\n    95| Host Vector | Kernel Vector | Host Mat Layout | Kernel Mat Layout \n    96|-------------|---------------|-----------------|------------------\n    97|   Row       |    Row        |    Row          |    Row\n    98|   Row       |    Row        |    Column       |    Column\n    99|   Column    |    Column     |    Row          |    Row\n   100|   Column    |    Column     |    Column       |    Column\n   101|   Row       |    Column     |    Row          |    Column\n   102|   Row       |    Column     |    Column       |    Row\n   103|   Column    |    Row        |    Row          |    Column\n   104|   Column    |    Row        |    Column       |    Row\n   105\n   106To be clear 'Kernel Mat Layout' is the shader matrix layout setting. As previously touched upon, if it is not possible to use the setting (say because it is not supported on a target), then doing a transpose at the host/kernel boundary can fix the issue. \n   107\n   108Matrix Layout\n   109-------------\n   110\n   111The above discussion is largely around 4x4 32-bit element matrices. For graphics APIs such as Vulkan, GL, and D3D there are typically additional restrictions for matrix layout. One restriction is for 16 byte alignment between rows (for `row-major` layout) and columns (for `column-major` layout). \n   112\n   113More CPU-like targets such as CUDA and C++/CPU do not have this restriction, and all elements are consecutive. \n   114\n   115This being the case only the following matrix types/matrix layouts will work across all targets. (Listed in the HLSL convention of RxC). \n   116 \n   117* 1x4 `row-major` matrix layout\n   118* 2x4 `row-major` matrix layout\n   119* 3x4 `row-major` matrix layout\n   120* 4x4 `row-major` matrix layout\n   121\n   122These are all 'row-major' because as previously discussed currently only `row-major` matrix layout works across all targets currently.\n   123\n   124NOTE! This only applies to matrices that are transferred between host and kernel - any matrix size will work appropriately for variables in shader/kernel code for example.\n   125\n   126The hosts maths library also plays a part here. The library may hold all elements consecutively in memory. If that's the case it will match the CPU/CUDA kernels, but will only work on 'graphics'-like targets that match that layout for the size. \n   127\n   128For SIMD based host maths libraries it can be even more convoluted. If a SIMD library is being used that prefers `row` vector interpretation and therefore will have `row-major` layout it may for many sizes *not* match the CPU-like consecutive layout. For example a 4x3 - it will likely be packed with 16 byte row alignment. Additionally even if a matrix is packed in the same way it may not be the same size. For example a 3x2 matrix *may* hold the rows consecutively *but* be 16 bytes in size, as opposed to the 12 bytes that a CPU-like kernel will expect. \n   129\n   130If a SIMD based host maths library with graphics-like APIs are being used, there is a good chance (but certainly *not* guaranteed) that layout across non 4x4 sizes will match because SIMD typically implies 16 byte alignment. \n   131\n   132If your application uses matrix sizes that are not 4x4 across the host/kernel boundary and it wants to work across all targets, it is *likely* that *some* matrices will have to be converted at the boundary. This being the case, having to handle transposing matrices at the boundary is a less significant issue. \n   133\n   134In conclusion, if your application has to perform matrix conversion work at the host/kernel boundary, the previous observation about \"best performance\" implying `row-major` layout and `row` vector interpretation becomes somewhat moot.\n   135\n   136Overriding default matrix layout\n   137--------------------------------\n   138\n   139Slang allows users to override default matrix layout with a compiler flag. This compiler flag can be specified during the creation of a `Session`:\n   140\n   141```\n   142slang::IGlobalSession* globalSession;\n   143...\n   144slang::SessionDesc slangSessionDesc = {};\n   145slangSessionDesc.defaultMatrixLayoutMode = SLANG_MATRIX_LAYOUT_COLUMN_MAJOR;\n   146...\n   147slang::ISession* session;\n   148globalSession->createSession(slangSessionDesc, &session);\n   149```\n   150\n   151This makes Slang treat all matrices as in `column-major` layout, and for example emitting `column_major` qualifier in resulting HLSL code.\n   152\n   153Alternatively the default layout can be set by\n   154\n   155* Including a `CompilerOptionName::MatrixLayoutColumn` or `CompilerOptionName::MatrixLayoutRow` entry in `SessionDesc::compilerOptionEntries`.\n   156* Setting `-matrix-layout-row-major` or `-matrix-layout-column-major` command line options to `slangc`.\n   157\n   158\n   159\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":"toolu_bdrk_01G3124YwHxP59x3i3RkifhR","session_id":"67c6a8ce-6f46-4571-9306-779ecfc46eb1"}
{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_bdrk_01XQKUuB7Xx5JCMpFwTi62Uq","type":"tool_result","content":"     1---\n     2layout: user-guide\n     3permalink: /user-guide/spirv-target-specific\n     4---\n     5\n     6SPIR-V-Specific Functionalities\n     7===============================\n     8\n     9This chapter provides information for SPIR-V specific functionalities and behaviors.\n    10\n    11Experimental support for the older versions of SPIR-V\n    12-----------------------------------------------------\n    13\n    14Slang's SPIR-V backend is stable when emitting SPIR-V 1.3 and later, however, support for SPIR-V 1.0, 1.1 and 1.2 is still experimental.\n    15When targeting the older SPIR-V profiles, Slang may produce SPIR-V that uses the instructions and keywords that were introduced in the later versions of SPIR-V.\n    16\n    17Memory model\n    18------------\n    19By default, the Slang compiler produces the SPIRV code using GLSL450 memory model. The user can opt-in to Vulkan Memory Model by specifying `-capability vk_mem_model`. For using APIs, the following lines can be added to explicitly specify the capability.\n    20```\n    21    slang::CompilerOptionEntry entry;\n    22    entry.name = slang::CompilerOptionName::Capability;\n    23    entry.value.kind = slang::CompilerOptionValueKind::String;\n    24    entry.value.stringValue0 = \"vk_mem_model\";\n    25\n    26    slang::SessionDesc sessionDesc = {};\n    27    sessionDesc.compilerOptionEntries = &entry;\n    28    sessionDesc.compilerOptionEntryCount = 1;\n    29```\n    30\n    31If the shader uses `CoopVec` or `CoopMat` intrinsics, then the Slang compiler will automatically use `vk_mem_model` capability.\n    32\n    33Combined texture sampler\n    34------------------------\n    35Slang supports Combined texture sampler such as `Sampler2D`.\n    36Slang emits SPIR-V code with `OpTypeSampledImage` instruction.\n    37\n    38For SPIR-V targets, explicit bindings may be provided through a single `vk::binding` decoration.\n    39```\n    40[[vk::binding(1,2)]]\n    41Sampler2D explicitBindingSampler;\n    42```\n    43\n    44For other targets (HLSL or others) where combined texture samplers are _not_ supported intrinsically, they are emulated by Slang using separate objects for Texture and Sampler.\n    45For explicit binding on such targets, you can specify two different register numbers for each: one for the texture register and another for the sampler register.\n    46```\n    47Sampler2D explicitBindingSampler : register(t4): register(s3);\n    48```\n    49\n    50\n    51System-Value semantics\n    52----------------\n    53\n    54The system-value semantics are translated to the following SPIR-V code.\n    55\n    56| SV semantic name              | SPIR-V Code                       |\n    57|-------------------------------|-----------------------------------|\n    58| `SV_Barycentrics`             | `BuiltIn BaryCoordKHR`            |\n    59| `SV_ClipDistance<N>`          | `BuiltIn ClipDistance`            |\n    60| `SV_CullDistance<N>`          | `BuiltIn CullDistance`            |\n    61| `SV_Coverage`                 | `BuiltIn SampleMask`              |\n    62| `SV_CullPrimitive`            | `BuiltIn CullPrimitiveEXT`        |\n    63| `SV_Depth`                    | `BuiltIn FragDepth`               |\n    64| `SV_DepthGreaterEqual`        | `BuiltIn FragDepth`               |\n    65| `SV_DepthLessEqual`           | `BuiltIn FragDepth`               |\n    66| `SV_DispatchThreadID`         | `BuiltIn GlobalInvocationId`      |\n    67| `SV_DomainLocation`           | `BuiltIn TessCoord`               |\n    68| `SV_DrawIndex`<sup>*</sup>    | `Builtin DrawIndex`               |\n    69| `SV_DeviceIndex`              | `Builtin DeviceIndex`             |\n    70| `SV_GSInstanceID`             | `BuiltIn InvocationId`            |\n    71| `SV_GroupID`                  | `BuiltIn WorkgroupId`             |\n    72| `SV_GroupIndex`               | `BuiltIn LocalInvocationIndex`    |\n    73| `SV_GroupThreadID`            | `BuiltIn LocalInvocationId`       |\n    74| `SV_InnerCoverage`            | `BuiltIn FullyCoveredEXT`         |\n    75| `SV_InsideTessFactor`         | `BuiltIn TessLevelInner`          |\n    76| `SV_InstanceID`<sup>**</sup>  | `BuiltIn InstanceIndex` - `Builtin BaseInstance`  |\n    77| `SV_IntersectionAttributes`   | *Not supported*                   |\n    78| `SV_IsFrontFace`              | `BuiltIn FrontFacing`             |\n    79| `SV_OutputControlPointID`     | `BuiltIn InvocationId`            |\n    80| `SV_PointSize`<sup>*</sup>    | `BuiltIn PointSize`               |\n    81| `SV_PointCoord`<sup>*</sup>   | `BuiltIn PointCoord`              |\n    82| `SV_Position`                 | `BuiltIn Position/FragCoord`      |\n    83| `SV_PrimitiveID`              | `BuiltIn PrimitiveId`             |\n    84| `SV_RenderTargetArrayIndex`   | `BuiltIn Layer`                   |\n    85| `SV_SampleIndex`              | `BuiltIn SampleId`                |\n    86| `SV_ShadingRate`              | `BuiltIn PrimitiveShadingRateKHR` |\n    87| `SV_StartVertexLocation`      | `BuiltIn BaseVertex`              |\n    88| `SV_StartInstanceLocation`    | `BuiltIn BaseInstance`            |\n    89| `SV_StencilRef`               | `BuiltIn FragStencilRefEXT`       |\n    90| `SV_Target<N>`                | `Location`                        |\n    91| `SV_TessFactor`               | `BuiltIn TessLevelOuter`          |\n    92| `SV_VertexID`<sup>**</sup>    | `BuiltIn VertexIndex` - `Builtin BaseVertex`    |\n    93| `SV_ViewID`                   | `BuiltIn ViewIndex`               |\n    94| `SV_ViewportArrayIndex`       | `BuiltIn ViewportIndex`           |\n    95| `SV_VulkanInstanceID`         | `BuiltIn InstanceIndex`           |\n    96| `SV_VulkanVertexID`           | `BuiltIn VertexIndex`             |\n    97\n    98*Note* that `SV_DrawIndex`, `SV_PointSize` and `SV_PointCoord` are Slang-specific semantics that are not defined in HLSL.\n    99Also *Note* that `SV_InstanceID`/`SV_VertexID` counts all instances/vertices in a draw call, unlike how `InstanceIndex`/`VertexIndex` is relative to `BaseInstance`/`BaseVertex`.\n   100See [Using SV_InstanceID/SV_VertexID with SPIR-V target](#using-sv_instanceid-and-sv_vertexid-with-spir-v-target)\n   101\n   102Using SV_InstanceID and SV_VertexID with SPIR-V target\n   103--------------------------------------\n   104\n   105When using `SV_InstanceID` and `SV_VertexID` with SPIR-V target, it is equivalent to the difference between the index and base builtins.\n   106This matches the behavior of D3D where `SV_InstanceID` and `SV_VertexID` starts from zero for each draw call, while in SPIR-V, \n   107`InstanceIndex` and `VertexIndex` includes the base instance.\n   108\n   109If you need direct access to `InstanceIndex` and `VertexIndex` values, use `SV_VulkanInstanceID` and `SV_VulkanVertexID` semantic names. These are supported for all targets except HLSL.\n   110Alternatively you can use parameters with `SV_InstanceID`(or `SV_VertexID`) and `SV_StartInstanceLocation`(or `SV_StartVertexLocation`) semantics:\n   111\n   112```slang\n   113void myVertexShader(\n   114    uint instanceID : SV_InstanceID,               // InstanceIndex - BaseInstance\n   115    uint baseInstance : SV_StartInstanceLocation)   // BaseInstance\n   116{\n   117    // If you need InstanceIndex, just add them:\n   118    uint instanceIndex = instanceID + baseInstance;\n   119\n   120    // Use instanceID, baseInstance, or instanceIndex as needed\n   121}\n   122```\n   123\n   124Behavior of `discard` after SPIR-V 1.6\n   125--------------------------------------\n   126\n   127`discard` is translated to OpKill in SPIR-V 1.5 and earlier. But it is translated to OpDemoteToHelperInvocation in SPIR-V 1.6.\n   128You can use OpDemoteToHelperInvocation by explicitly specifying the capability, \"SPV_EXT_demote_to_helper_invocation\".\n   129\n   130As an example, the following command-line arguments can control the behavior of `discard` when targeting SPIR-V.\n   131```\n   132slangc.exe test.slang -target spir-v -profile spir-v_1_5 # emits OpKill \n   133slangc.exe test.slang -target spir-v -profile spir-v_1_6 # emits OpDemoteToHelperInvocation \n   134slangc.exe test.slang -target spir-v -capability SPV_EXT_demote_to_helper_invocation -profile spir-v_1_5 # emits OpDemoteToHelperInvocation \n   135```\n   136\n   137\n   138Supported HLSL features when targeting SPIR-V\n   139---------------------------------------------\n   140\n   141Slang supports the following HLSL feature sets when targeting SPIR-V.\n   142 - ray tracing,\n   143 - inline ray tracing,\n   144 - mesh shader,\n   145 - tessellation shader,\n   146 - geometry shader,\n   147 - wave intrinsics,\n   148 - barriers,\n   149 - atomics,\n   150 - and more\n   151\n   152\n   153Unsupported GLSL keywords when targeting SPIR-V\n   154-----------------------------------------------\n   155\n   156Slang doesn't support the following Precision qualifiers in Vulkan.\n   157 - lowp : RelaxedPrecision, on storage variable and operation\n   158 - mediump : RelaxedPrecision, on storage variable and operation\n   159 - highp : 32-bit, same as int or float\n   160\n   161Slang ignores the keywords above and all of them are treated as `highp`.\n   162\n   163\n   164Supported atomic types for each target\n   165--------------------------------------\n   166Shader Model 6.2 introduced [16-bit scalar types](https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/wiki/16-Bit-Scalar-Types) such as `float16` and `int16_t`, but they didn't come with any atomic operations.\n   167Shader Model 6.6 introduced [atomic operations for 64-bit integer types and bitwise atomic operations for 32-bit float type](https://microsoft.github.io/DirectX-Specs/d3d/HLSL_SM_6_6_Int64_and_Float_Atomics.html), but 16-bit integer types and 16-bit float types are not a part of it.\n   168\n   169[GLSL 4.3](https://registry.khronos.org/OpenGL/specs/gl/GLSLangSpec.4.30.pdf) introduced atomic operations for 32-bit integer types.\n   170GLSL 4.4 with [GL_EXT_shader_atomic_int64](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/GLSL/blob/main/extensions/ext/GL_EXT_shader_atomic_int64.txt) can use atomic operations for 64-bit integer types.\n   171GLSL 4.6 with [GLSL_EXT_shader_atomic_float](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/GLSL/blob/main/extensions/ext/GLSL_EXT_shader_atomic_float.txt) can use atomic operations for 32-bit float type.\n   172GLSL 4.6 with [GLSL_EXT_shader_atomic_float2](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/GLSL/blob/main/extensions/ext/GLSL_EXT_shader_atomic_float2.txt) can use atomic operations for 16-bit float type.\n   173\n   174SPIR-V 1.5 with [SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float_add](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/SPIRV-Registry/blob/main/extensions/EXT/SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float_add.asciidoc) and [SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float_min_max](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/SPIRV-Registry/blob/main/extensions/EXT/SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float_min_max.asciidoc) can use atomic operations for 32-bit float type and 64-bit float type.\n   175SPIR-V 1.5 with [SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float16_add](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/SPIRV-Registry/blob/main/extensions/EXT/SPV_EXT_shader_atomic_float16_add.asciidoc) can use atomic operations for 16-bit float type\n   176\n   177|        |  32-bit integer | 64-bit integer  |      32-bit float     |  64-bit float    |   16-bit float   |\n   178|--------|-----------------|-----------------|-----------------------|------------------|------------------|\n   179| HLSL   |   Yes (SM5.0)   |   Yes (SM6.6)   | Only bit-wise (SM6.6) |       No         |      No          |\n   180| GLSL   |   Yes (GL4.3)   | Yes (GL4.4+ext) |    Yes (GL4.6+ext)    | Yes (GL4.6+ext)  | Yes (GL4.6+ext)  |\n   181| SPIR-V |   Yes           |     Yes         |    Yes (SPV1.5+ext)   | Yes (SPV1.5+ext) | Yes (SPV1.5+ext) |\n   182\n   183\n   184ConstantBuffer, StructuredBuffer and ByteAddressBuffer\n   185-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n   186\n   187Each member in a `ConstantBuffer` will be emitted as `uniform` parameter in a uniform block.\n   188StructuredBuffer and ByteAddressBuffer are translated to a shader storage buffer with `readonly` access.\n   189RWStructuredBuffer and RWByteAddressBuffer are translated to a shader storage buffer with `read-write` access.\n   190RasterizerOrderedStructuredBuffer and RasterizerOrderedByteAddressBuffer will use an extension, `SPV_EXT_fragment_shader_interlock`.\n   191\n   192If you need to apply a different buffer layout for individual `ConstantBuffer` or `StructuredBuffer`, you can specify the layout as a second generic argument. E.g., `ConstantBuffer<T, Std430DataLayout>`, `StructuredBuffer<T, Std140DataLayout>`, `StructuredBuffer<T, Std430DataLayout>` or `StructuredBuffer<T, ScalarDataLayout>`.\n   193\n   194Note that there are compiler options, \"-fvk-use-scalar-layout\" / \"-force-glsl-scalar-layout\" and \"-fvk-use-dx-layout\".\n   195These options do the same but they are applied globally.\n   196\n   197\n   198ParameterBlock for SPIR-V target\n   199--------------------------------\n   200\n   201`ParameterBlock` is a Slang generic type for binding uniform parameters.\n   202In contrast to `ConstantBuffer`, a `ParameterBlock<T>` introduces a new descriptor set ID for resource/sampler handles defined in the element type `T`.\n   203\n   204`ParameterBlock` is designed specifically for D3D12/Vulkan/Metal/WebGPU, so that parameters defined in `T` can be placed into an independent descriptor table/descriptor set/argument buffer/binding group.\n   205\n   206For example, when targeting Vulkan, when a ParameterBlock doesn't contain nested parameter block fields, it will always map to a single descriptor set, with a dedicated set number and every resources is placed into the set with binding index starting from 0. This allows the user application to create and pre-populate the descriptor set and reuse it during command encoding, without explicitly specifying the binding index for each individual parameter.\n   207\n   208When both ordinary data fields and resource typed fields exist in a parameter block, all ordinary data fields will be grouped together into a uniform buffer and appear as a binding 0 of the resulting descriptor set.\n   209\n   210\n   211Push Constants\n   212---------------------\n   213\n   214By default, a `uniform` parameter defined in the parameter list of an entrypoint function is translated to a push constant in SPIRV, if the type of the parameter is ordinary data type (no resources/textures).\n   215All `uniform` parameters defined in global scope are grouped together and placed in a default constant buffer. You can make a global uniform parameter laid out as a push constant by using the `[vk::push_constant]` attribute\n   216on the uniform parameter. All push constants follow the std430 layout by default.\n   217\n   218Specialization Constants\n   219------------------------\n   220\n   221You can specify a global constant to translate into a SPIRV specialization constant with the `[SpecializationConstant]` attribute.\n   222For example:\n   223```csharp\n   224[SpecializationConstant]\n   225const int myConst = 1; // Maps to a SPIRV specialization constant\n   226```\n   227\n   228By default, Slang will automatically assign `constant_id` number for specialization constants. If you wish to explicitly specify them, use `[vk::constant_id]` attribute:\n   229```csharp\n   230[vk::constant_id(1)]\n   231const int myConst = 1;\n   232```\n   233\n   234Alternatively, the GLSL `layout` syntax is also supported by Slang:\n   235```glsl\n   236layout(constant_id = 1) const int MyConst = 1;\n   237```\n   238\n   239SPIR-V specific Attributes \n   240--------------------------\n   241\n   242DXC supports a few attributes and command-line arguments for targeting SPIR-V. Similar to DXC, Slang supports a few of the attributes as following:\n   243\n   244### [[vk::binding(binding: int, set: int = 0)]]\n   245Similar to `binding` layout qualifier in Vulkan. It specifies the uniform buffer binding point, and the descriptor set for Vulkan.\n   246\n   247### [[vk::location(X)]]\n   248Same as `location` layout qualifier in Vulkan. For vertex shader inputs, it specifies the number of the vertex attribute from which input values are taken. For inputs of all other shader types, the location specifies a vector number that can be used to match against outputs from a previous shader stage.\n   249\n   250### [[vk::index(Y)]]\n   251Same as `index` layout qualifier in Vulkan. It is valid only when used with [[location(X)]]. For fragment shader outputs, the location and index specify the color output number and index receiving the values of the output. For outputs of all other shader stages, the location specifies a vector number that can be used to match against inputs in a subsequent shader stage.\n   252\n   253### [[vk::input_attachment_index(i)]]\n   254Same as `input_attachment_index` layout qualifier in Vulkan. It selects which subpass input is being read from. It is valid only when used on subpassInput type uniform variables.\n   255\n   256### [[vk::push_constant]]\n   257Same as `push_constant` layout qualifier in Vulkan. It is applicable only to a uniform block and it will be copied to a special memory location where GPU may have a more direct access to.\n   258\n   259### [vk::image_format(format : String)]\n   260Same as `[[vk::image_format(\"XX\")]]` layout qualifier in DXC. Vulkan/GLSL allows the format string to be specified without the keyword, `image_format`.  Consider the following Slang code, as an example,\n   261```csharp\n   262[vk::image_format(\"r32f\")] RWTexture2D<float> typicalTexture;\n   263```\n   264It will generate the following GLSL,\n   265> layout(r32f) uniform image2D typicalTexture_0;\n   266\n   267Or it will generate the following SPIR-V code,\n   268> %18 = OpTypeImage %float 2D 2 0 0 2 R32f\n   269\n   270### [vk::shader_record]\n   271Same as `shaderRecordEXT` layout qualifier in [GL_EXT_ray_tracing extension](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/GLSL/blob/main/extensions/ext/GLSL_EXT_ray_tracing.txt).\n   272It can be used on a buffer block that represents a buffer within a shader record as defined in the Ray Tracing API.\n   273\n   274\n   275Multiple entry points support\n   276-----------------------------\n   277\n   278To use multiple entry points, you will need to use a compiler option, `-fvk-use-entrypoint-name`.\n   279\n   280Because GLSL requires the entry point to be named, \"main\", a GLSL shader can have only one entry point.\n   281The default behavior of Slang is to rename all entry points to \"main\" when targeting SPIR-V.\n   282\n   283When there are more than one entry point, the default behavior will prevent a shader from having more than one entry point.\n   284To generate a valid SPIR-V with multiple entry points, use `-fvk-use-entrypoint-name` compiler option to disable the renaming behavior and preserve the entry point names.\n   285\n   286\n   287Global memory pointers\n   288------------------------------\n   289\n   290Slang supports global memory pointers when targeting SPIRV. See [an example and explanation](03-convenience-features.html#pointers-limited).\n   291\n   292`float4*` in user code will be translated to a pointer in PhysicalStorageBuffer storage class in SPIRV.\n   293When a slang module uses a pointer type, the resulting SPIRV will be using the SpvAddressingModelPhysicalStorageBuffer64 addressing mode. Modules without use of pointers will use SpvAddressingModelLogical addressing mode.\n   294\n   295\n   296Matrix type translation\n   297-----------------------\n   298\n   299A m-row-by-n-column matrix in Slang, represented as float`m`x`n` or matrix<T, m, n>, is translated to OpTypeMatrix (OpTypeVector(T, n), m) in SPIRV. Note that in SPIR-V terminology, this type is referred to a m-column-by-n-row matrix.\n   300\n   301The swap of row and column terminology may seem to be confusing at first, but this is the only translation without needing extra operations that may have negative performance consequences. For example, consider the following Slang code:\n   302```\n   303float3x4 v;\n   304for (int i = 0; i < 3; ++i)\n   305{\n   306  for (int j = 0; j < 4; ++j)\n   307  {\n   308    v[i][j] = i * 4 + j;\n   309  }\n   310}\n   311```\n   312The Slang shader above can iterate each element of a `float3x4` matrix. This is similar to how a multi-dimensional array is handled in C and HLSL. When a matrix type is `float3x4`, the first dimension indexing, `i`, corresponds to the first value specified in the matrix type `3`. And the second dimension indexing, `j`, corresponds to the second value specified in the matrix type `4`.\n   313\n   314A matrix in Slang can be also seen as an array of a vector type. And the following code is same as above.\n   315```\n   316float3x4 v;\n   317for (int i = 0; i < 3; ++i)\n   318{\n   319  v[i] = float4(0, 1, 2, 3);\n   320  v[i] += i * 4;\n   321}\n   322```\n   323\n   324For the given example above, when targeting SPIR-V, Slang emits a matrix that consists of three vectors each of which has four elements,\n   325```\n   326%float = OpTypeFloat 32\n   327%v4float = OpTypeVector %float 4 ; <= float4 type\n   328%mat3v4float = OpTypeMatrix %v4float 3 ; <= three of float4\n   329```\n   330\n   331An alternative way to emit SPIR-V code is to emit four vectors and each vector has three elements. Slang doesn't do this but this is a more direct translation because SPIR-V spec defines OpTypeMatrix to take \"Column Count\" not row.\n   332```\n   333; NOT SLANG EMITTED CODE\n   334%v3float = OpTypeVector %float 3 ; <= float3 type\n   335%mat4v3float = OpTypeMatrix %v3float 4 ; <= four of float3\n   336```\n   337However, this results in a more complicated access pattern to the elements in a matrix, because `v[i]` will no longer correspond to a vector natively when emitted to SPIR-V.\n   338\n   339Another way to put, Slang treats column as row and row as column when targeting GLSL or SPIR-V. This is same to [how DXC handles a matrix when emitting SPIR-V](https://github.com/Microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/blob/main/docs/SPIR-V.rst#appendix-a-matrix-representation).\n   340\n   341Due to the swap of row and column in terminology, the matrix multiplication needs to be performed little differently. Slang translates a matrix multiplication, `mul(mat1, mat2)`, to `transpose(mul(transpose(mat2), transpose(mat1)))` when targeting SPIR-V.\n   342\n   343Note that the matrix translation explained above is orthogonal to the memory layout of a matrix. The memory layout is related to how CPU places matrix values in the memory and how GPU reads them. It is like how `std140` or `std430` works. DXC by default uses `column_major` memory layout and Slang uses row-major memory layout. For more information about the matrix memory layout, please see [a1-01-matrix-layout](a1-01-matrix-layout.md).\n   344\n   345\n   346Legalization\n   347------------\n   348\n   349Legalization is a process where Slang applies slightly different approach to translate the input Slang shader to the target.\n   350This process allows Slang shaders to be written in a syntax that SPIR-V may not be able to achieve natively.\n   351\n   352Slang allows to use opaque resource types as members of a struct. These members will be hoisted out of struct types and become global variables.\n   353\n   354Slang allows functions that return any resource types as return type or `out` parameter as long as things are statically resolvable.\n   355\n   356Slang allows functions that return arrays. These functions will be converted to return the array via an out parameter in SPIRV.\n   357\n   358Slang allows putting scalar/vector/matrix/array types directly as element type of a constant buffer or structured buffers. Such element types will be wrapped in a struct type when emitting to SPIRV.\n   359\n   360When RasterizerOrder resources are used, the order of the rasterization is guaranteed by the instructions from `SPV_EXT_fragment_shader_interlock` extension.\n   361\n   362A `StructuredBuffer` with a primitive type such as `StructuredBuffer<int> v` is translated to a buffer with a struct that has the primitive type, which is more like `struct Temp { int v; }; StructuredBuffer<Temp> v;`. It is because, SPIR-V requires buffer variables to be declared within a named buffer block.\n   363\n   364When `pervertex` keyword is used, the given type for the varying input will be translated into an array of the given type whose element size is 3. It is because each triangle consists of three vertices.\n   365\n   366\n   367Tessellation\n   368------------\n   369\n   370In HLSL and Slang, Hull shader requires two functions: a Hull shader and patch function.\n   371A typical example of a Hull shader will look like the following.\n   372```\n   373// Hull Shader (HS)\n   374[domain(\"quad\")]\n   375[patchconstantfunc(\"constants\")]\n   376HS_OUT main(InputPatch<VS_OUT, 4> patch, uint i : SV_OutputControlPointID)\n   377{\n   378  ...\n   379}\n   380HSC_OUT constants(InputPatch<VS_OUT, 4> patch)\n   381{\n   382  ...\n   383}\n   384```\n   385\n   386When targeting SPIR-V, the patch function is merged as a part of the Hull shader, because SPIR-V doesn't have a same concept as `patchconstantfunc`.\n   387The function used for `patchconstantfunc` should be called only once for each patch.\n   388\n   389As an example, the Hull shader above will be emitted as following,\n   390```\n   391void main() {\n   392    ...\n   393    main(patch, gl_InvocationID);\n   394    barrier(); // OpControlBarrier\n   395    if (gl_InvocationID == 0)\n   396    {\n   397        constants(path);\n   398    }\n   399}\n   400```\n   401\n   402This behavior is same to [how DXC translates Hull shader from HLSL to SPIR-V](https://github.com/Microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/blob/main/docs/SPIR-V.rst#patch-constant-function).\n   403\n   404\n   405SPIR-V specific Compiler options\n   406--------------------------------\n   407\n   408The following compiler options are specific to SPIR-V.\n   409\n   410### -emit-spirv-directly\n   411Generate SPIR-V output directly (default)\n   412It cannot be used with -emit-spirv-via-glsl\n   413\n   414### -emit-spirv-via-glsl\n   415Generate SPIR-V output by compiling to glsl source first, then use glslang compiler to produce SPIRV from the glsl.\n   416It cannot be used with -emit-spirv-directly\n   417\n   418### -g\n   419Include debug information in the generated code, where possible.\n   420When targeting SPIR-V, this option emits [SPIR-V NonSemantic Shader DebugInfo Instructions](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/SPIRV-Registry/blob/main/nonsemantic/NonSemantic.Shader.DebugInfo.100.asciidoc).\n   421\n   422### -O<optimization-level>\n   423Set the optimization level.\n   424Under `-O0` option, Slang will not perform extensive inlining for all functions calls, instead it will preserve the call graph as much as possible to help with understanding the SPIRV structure and diagnosing any downstream toolchain issues.\n   425\n   426### -fvk-{b|s|t|u}-shift <N> <space>\n   427For example '-fvk-b-shift <N> <space>' shifts by N the inferred binding\n   428numbers for all resources in 'b' registers of space <space>. For a resource attached with :register(bX, <space>)\n   429but not [vk::binding(...)], sets its Vulkan descriptor set to <space> and binding number to X + N. If you need to\n   430shift the inferred binding numbers for more than one space, provide more than one such option. If more than one\n   431such option is provided for the same space, the last one takes effect. If you need to shift the inferred binding\n   432numbers for all sets, use 'all' as <space>.\n   433\n   434For more information, see the following pages:\n   435 - [DXC description](https://github.com/Microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/blob/main/docs/SPIR-V.rst#implicit-binding-number-assignment)\n   436 - [GLSL wiki](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glslang/wiki/HLSL-FAQ#auto-mapped-binding-numbers)\n   437\n   438### -fvk-bind-globals <N> <descriptor-set>\n   439Places the $Globals cbuffer at descriptor set <descriptor-set> and binding <N>.\n   440It lets you specify the descriptor for the source at a certain register.\n   441\n   442For more information, see the following pages:\n   443 - [DXC description](https://github.com/Microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/blob/main/docs/SPIR-V.rst#hlsl-global-variables-and-vulkan-binding)\n   444\n   445### -fvk-use-scalar-layout, -force-glsl-scalar-layout\n   446Make data accessed through ConstantBuffer, ParameterBlock, StructuredBuffer, ByteAddressBuffer and general pointers follow the 'scalar' layout when targeting GLSL or SPIRV.\n   447\n   448### -fvk-use-gl-layout\n   449Use std430 layout instead of D3D buffer layout for raw buffer load/stores.\n   450\n   451### -fvk-use-dx-layout\n   452Pack members using FXCs member packing rules when targeting GLSL or SPIRV.\n   453\n   454### -fvk-use-entrypoint-name\n   455Uses the entrypoint name from the source instead of 'main' in the spirv output.\n   456\n   457### -fspv-reflect\n   458Include reflection decorations in the resulting SPIR-V for shader parameters.\n   459\n   460### -spirv-core-grammar\n   461A path to a specific spirv.core.grammar.json to use when generating SPIR-V output\n   462\n   463\n   464\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":"toolu_bdrk_01G3124YwHxP59x3i3RkifhR","session_id":"67c6a8ce-6f46-4571-9306-779ecfc46eb1"}

Returns SLANG_OK when the cache is sucessfully loaded. Also returns the filename to\n    30// the builtin module cache and the timestamp of current slang dll.\n    31SlangResult tryLoadBuiltinModuleFromCache(\n    32    slang::IGlobalSession* globalSession,\n    33    slang::BuiltinModuleName builtinModuleName,\n    34    Slang::String& outCachePath,\n    35    uint64_t& outTimestamp)\n    36{\n    37    auto fileName =\n    38        Slang::SharedLibraryUtils::getSharedLibraryFileName((void*)slang_createGlobalSession);\n    39    uint64_t currentLibTimestamp =\n    40        Slang::SharedLibraryUtils::getSharedLibraryTimestamp((void*)slang_createGlobalSession);\n    41    auto dirName = Slang::Path::getParentDirectory(fileName);\n    42    auto cacheFileName = Slang::Path::combine(\n    43        dirName,\n    44        Slang::String(\"slang-\") + Slang::getBuiltinModuleNameStr(builtinModuleName) +\n    45            \"-module.bin\");\n    46    outTimestamp = currentLibTimestamp;\n    47    outCachePath = cacheFileName;\n    48    if (currentLibTimestamp == 0)\n    49    {\n    50        return SLANG_FAIL;\n    51    }\n    52    Slang::ScopedAllocation cacheData;\n    53    SLANG_RETURN_ON_FAIL(Slang::File::readAllBytes(cacheFileName, cacheData));\n    54\n    55    // The first 8 bytes stores the timestamp of the slang dll that created this core module cache.\n    56    if (cacheData.getSizeInBytes() < sizeof(uint64_t))\n    57        return SLANG_FAIL;\n    58    auto cacheTimestamp = *(uint64_t*)(cacheData.getData());\n    59    if (cacheTimestamp != currentLibTimestamp)\n    60        return SLANG_FAIL;\n    61    SLANG_RETURN_ON_FAIL(globalSession->loadBuiltinModule(\n    62        builtinModuleName,\n    63        (uint8_t*)cacheData.getData() + sizeof(uint64_t),\n    64        cacheData.getSizeInBytes() - sizeof(uint64_t)));\n    65    return SLANG_OK;\n    66}\n    67\n    68// Attempt to load a precompiled builtin module from slang-xxx-module.dll.\n    69SlangResult tryLoadBuiltinModuleFromDLL(\n    70    slang::IGlobalSession* globalSession,\n    71    slang::BuiltinModuleName builtinModuleName)\n    72{\n    73    Slang::String moduleFileName =\n    74        Slang::String(\"slang-\") + Slang::getBuiltinModuleNameStr(builtinModuleName) + \"-module\";\n    75\n    76    Slang::SharedLibrary::Handle libHandle = nullptr;\n    77\n    78    SLANG_RETURN_ON_FAIL(Slang::SharedLibrary::load(moduleFileName.getBuffer(), libHandle));\n    79    if (!libHandle)\n    80        return SLANG_FAIL;\n    81    void* ptr = Slang::SharedLibrary::findSymbolAddressByName(libHandle, \"slang_getEmbeddedModule\");\n    82    if (!ptr)\n    83        return SLANG_FAIL;\n    84    typedef ISlangBlob*(GetEmbeddedModuleFunc)();\n    85    auto getEmbeddedModule = (GetEmbeddedModuleFunc*)ptr;\n    86    auto blob = getEmbeddedModule();\n    87    SLANG_RETURN_ON_FAIL(globalSession->loadBuiltinModule(\n    88        builtinModuleName,\n    89        (uint8_t*)blob->getBufferPointer(),\n    90        blob->getBufferSize()));\n    91    return SLANG_OK;\n    92}\n    93\n    94SlangResult trySaveBuiltinModuleToCache(\n    95    slang::IGlobalSession* globalSession,\n    96    slang::BuiltinModuleName builtinModuleName,\n    97    const Slang::String& cacheFilename,\n    98    uint64_t dllTimestamp)\n    99{\n   100    if (dllTimestamp != 0 && cacheFilename.getLength() != 0)\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":"toolu_bdrk_01BiBNUK5ETf1Khj7xKbbL9N","session_id":"67c6a8ce-6f46-4571-9306-779ecfc46eb1"}

(void*)&callback);\n   512    }\n   513\n   514    /// Side-band information generated when specializing this component type.\n   515    ///\n   516    /// Difference subclasses of `ComponentType` are expected to create their\n   517    /// own subclass of `SpecializationInfo` as the output of `_validateSpecializationArgs`.\n   518    /// Later, whenever we want to use a specialized component type we will\n   519    /// also have the `SpecializationInfo` available and will expect it to\n   520    /// have the correct (subclass-specific) type.\n   521    ///\n   522    class SpecializationInfo : public RefObject\n   523    {\n   524    };\n   525\n   526    /// Validate the given specialization `args` and compute any side-band specialization info.\n   527    ///\n   528    /// Any errors will be reported to `sink`, which can thus be used to test\n   529    /// if the operation was successful.\n   530    ///\n   531    /// A null return value is allowed, since not all subclasses require\n   532    /// custom side-band specialization information.\n   533    ///\n   534    /// This function is an implementation detail of `specialize()`.\n   535    ///\n   536    virtual RefPtr<SpecializationInfo> _validateSpecializationArgsImpl(\n   537        SpecializationArg const* args,\n   538        Index argCount,\n   539        DiagnosticSink* sink) = 0;\n   540\n   541    /// Validate the given specialization `args` and compute any side-band specialization info.\n   542    ///\n   543    /// Any errors will be reported to `sink`, which can thus be used to test\n   544    /// if the operation was successful.\n   545    ///\n   546    /// A null return value is allowed, since not all subclasses require\n   547    /// custom side-band specialization information.\n   548    ///\n   549    /// This function is an implementation detail of `specialize()`.\n   550    ///\n   551    RefPtr<SpecializationInfo> _validateSpecializationArgs(\n   552        SpecializationArg const* args,\n   553        Index argCount,\n   554        DiagnosticSink* sink)\n   555    {\n   556        if (argCount == 0)\n   557            return nullptr;\n   558        return _validateSpecializationArgsImpl(args, argCount, sink);\n   559    }\n   560\n   561    /// Specialize this component type given `specializationArgs`\n   562    ///\n   563    /// Any diagnostics will be reported to `sink`, which can be used\n   564    /// to determine if the operation was successful. It is allowed\n   565    /// for this operation to have a non-null return even when an\n   566    /// error is ecnountered.\n   567    ///\n   568    RefPtr<ComponentType> specialize(\n   569        SpecializationArg const* specializationArgs,\n   570        SlangInt specializationArgCount,\n   571        DiagnosticSink* sink);\n   572\n   573    /// Invoke `visitor` on this component type, using the appropriate dynamic type.\n   574    ///\n   575    /// This function implements the \"visitor pattern\" for `ComponentType`.\n   576    ///\n   577    /// If the `specializationInfo` argument is non-null, it must be specialization\n   578    /// information generated for this specific component type by `_validateSpecializationArgs`.\n   579    /// In that case, appropriately-typed specialization information will be passed\n   580    /// when invoking the `visitor`.\n   581    ///\n   582    virtual void acceptVisitor(\n   583        ComponentTypeVisitor* visitor,\n   584        SpecializationInfo* specializationInfo) = 0;\n   585\n   586    /// Create a scope suitable for looking up names or parsing specialization arguments.\n   587    ///\n   588    /// This facility is only needed to support legacy APIs for string-based lookup\n   589    /// and parsing via Slang reflection, and is not recommended for future APIs to use.\n   590    ///\n   591    Scope* _getOrCreateScopeForLegacyLookup(ASTBuilder* astBuilder);\n   592\n   593protected:\n   594    ComponentType(Linkage* linkage);\n   595\n   596protected:\n   597    Linkage* m_linkage;\n   598\n   599    CompilerOptionSet m_optionSet;\n   600\n   601    // Cache of target-specific programs for each target.\n   602    Dictionary<TargetRequest*, RefPtr<TargetProgram>> m_targetPrograms;\n   603\n   604    // Any types looked up dynamically using `getTypeFromString`\n   605    //\n   606    // TODO: Remove this. Type lookup should only be supported on `Module`s.\n   607    //\n   608    Dictionary<String, Type*> m_types;\n   609\n   610    // Any decls looked up dynamically using `findDeclFromString`.\n   611    Dictionary<String, Expr*> m_decls;\n   612\n   613    Scope* m_lookupScope = nullptr;\n   614    std::unique_ptr<Dictionary<String, IntVal*>> m_mapMangledNameToIntVal;\n   615\n   616    Dictionary<Int, ComPtr<IArtifact>> m_targetArtifacts;\n   617};\n   618\n   619/// A component type built up from other component types.\n   620class CompositeComponentType : public ComponentType\n   621{\n   622public:\n   623    static RefPtr<ComponentType> create(\n   624        Linkage* linkage,\n   625        List<RefPtr<ComponentType>> const& childComponents);\n   626\n   627    virtual void buildHash(DigestBuilder<SHA1>& builder) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   628\n   629    List<RefPtr<ComponentType>> const& getChildComponents() { return m_childComponents; };\n   630    Index getChildComponentCount() { return m_childComponents.getCount(); }\n   631    RefPtr<ComponentType> getChildComponent(Index index) { return m_childComponents[index]; }\n   632\n   633    Index getEntryPointCount() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   634    RefPtr<EntryPoint> getEntryPoint(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   635    String getEntryPointMangledName(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   636    String getEntryPointNameOverride(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   637\n   638    Index getShaderParamCount() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   639    ShaderParamInfo getShaderParam(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   640\n   641    SLANG_NO_THROW Index SLANG_MCALL getSpecializationParamCount() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   642    SpecializationParam const& getSpecializationParam(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   643\n   644    Index getRequirementCount() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   645    RefPtr<ComponentType> getRequirement(Index index) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   646\n   647    List<Module*> const& getModuleDependencies() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   648    List<SourceFile*> const& getFileDependencies() SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   649\n   650    class CompositeSpecializationInfo : public SpecializationInfo\n   651    {\n   652    public:\n   653        List<RefPtr<SpecializationInfo>> childInfos;\n   654    };\n   655\n   656protected:\n   657    void acceptVisitor(ComponentTypeVisitor* visitor, SpecializationInfo* specializationInfo)\n   658        SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   659\n   660\n   661    RefPtr<SpecializationInfo> _validateSpecializationArgsImpl(\n   662        SpecializationArg const* args,\n   663        Index argCount,\n   664        DiagnosticSink* sink) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   665\n   666public:\n   667    CompositeComponentType(Linkage* linkage, List<RefPtr<ComponentType>> const& childComponents);\n   668\n   669private:\n   670    List<RefPtr<ComponentType>> m_childComponents;\n   671\n   672    // The following arrays hold the concatenated entry points, parameters,\n   673    // etc. from the child components. This approach allows for reasonably\n   674    // fast (constant time) access through operations like `getShaderParam`,\n   675    // but means that the memory usage of a composite is proportional to\n   676    // the sum of the memory usage of the children, rather than being fixed\n   677    // by the number of children (as it would be if we just stored\n   678    // `m_childComponents`).\n   679    //\n   680    // TODO: We could conceivably build some O(numChildren) arrays that\n   681    // support binary-search to provide logarithmic-time access to entry\n   682    // points, parameters, etc. while giving a better overall memory usage.\n   683    //\n   684    List<EntryPoint*> m_entryPoints;\n   685    List<String> m_entryPointMangledNames;\n   686    List<String> m_entryPointNameOverrides;\n   687    List<ShaderParamInfo> m_shaderParams;\n   688    List<SpecializationParam> m_specializationParams;\n   689    List<ComponentType*> m_requirements;\n   690\n   691    ModuleDependencyList m_moduleDependencyList;\n   692    FileDependencyList m_fileDependencyList;\n   693};\n   694\n   695/// A component type created by specializing another component type.\n 918};\n   919\n   920/// Describes an entry point for the purposes of layout and code generation.\n   921///\n   922/// This class also tracks any generic arguments to the entry point,\n   923/// in the case that it is a specialization of a generic entry point.\n   924///\n   925/// There is also a provision for creating a \"dummy\" entry point for\n   926/// the purposes of pass-through compilation modes. SlangPassThroughIntegral\n  1431{\n  1432    None = SLANG_PASS_THROUGH_NONE,                  ///< don't pass through: use Slang compiler\n  1433    Fxc = SLANG_PASS_THROUGH_FXC, defined in the module are *not*\n  1894    // part of the memory image/layout of the module when\n  1895    // it is considered as an IComponentType. This can be\n  1896    // a bit confusing, but if all the entry points in the\n  1897    // module were automatically linked into the component\n  1898    // type, we'd need a way to access just the global\n  1899    // scope of the module without the entry points, in\n  1900    // case we wanted to link a single entry point against\n  1901    // the global scope. The `Module` type provides exactly\n  1902    // that \"module without its entry points\" unit of\n  1903    // granularity for linking.\n  1904    //\n  1905    // This list only exists for lookup   {\n  1926        if (!outDisassembledBlob)\n  1927            return SLANG_E_INVALID_ARG;\n  1928        String disassembly;\n  1929        this->getIRModule()->getModuleInst()->dump(disassembly);\n  1930        auto blob = StringUtil::createStringBlob(disassembly);\n  1931        *outDisassembledBlob = blob.detach();\n  1932        return SLANG_OK;\n  1933    }\n  1934};\n  1935typedef Module LoadedModule;\n  1936\n  1937/// A request for the front-end to compile a translation unit.\n  1938class TranslationUnitRequest : public RefObject\n  1939{\n  1940public:\n  1941   // TypeLayouts created on the fly by reflection API\n  2101    struct TypeLayoutKey\n  2102    {\n  2103        Type* type;\n  2104        slang::LayoutRules rules;\n  2105        HashCode getHashCode() const\n  2106        {\n  2107            Hasher hasher;\n  2108            hasher.hashValue(type);\n  2109            hasher.hashValue(rules);\n  2110            return hasher.getResult();\n  2111        }\n  2112        bool operator==(TypeLayoutKey other) const\n  2113        {\n  2114            return type == other.type && rules == other.rules;\n  2115        }\n  2116    };\n  2117    Dictionary<TypeLayoutKey, RefPtr<TypeLayout>> typeLayouts;\n  2118\n  2119    Dictionary<TypeLayoutKey, RefPtr<TypeLayout>>& getTypeLayouts() { return typeLayouts; }\n  2120\n returns which (if any) intermediate source language is required\n  2139/// to produce it.\n  2140///\n  2141/// If no intermediate source language is required, will return SourceLanguage::Unknown\n  2142SourceLanguage getIntermediateSourceLanguageForTarget(TargetProgram* req);\n  2143\n  2144/// Are resource types \"bindless\" (implemented as ordinary data) on the given `target`?\n  2145bool areResourceTypesBindlessOnTarget(TargetRequest* target);\n  2146\n  2147// Compute the \"effective\" profile to use when outputting the given entry point\n  2148// for the chosen code-generation target.\n  2149//\n  2150// The stage of the effective profile will always come from the entry point, while\n  2151// the profile version (aka \"shader model\") will be computed as follows:\n  2152//\n  2153// - If the entry point and target belong to the same profile family, then take\n  2154//   the latest version between the two (e.g., if the entry point specified `ps_5_1`\n  2155//   and the target specifies `sm_5_0` then use `sm_5_1` as the version).\n  2156//\n  2157// - If the entry point and target disagree on the profile family, always use the\n  2158//   profile family and version from the target.\n  2159//\n  2160Profile getEffectiveProfile(EntryPoint* entryPoint, TargetRequest* target);\n  2161\n  2162\n  2163/// Given a target returns the required downstream compiler\n  2164PassThroughMode getDownstreamCompilerRequiredForTarget(CodeGenTarget target);\n  2165/// Given a target returns a downstream compiler the prelude should be taken from.\n  2166SourceLanguage getDefaultSourceLanguageForDownstreamCompiler(PassThroughMode compiler);\n  2167\n  2168/// Get the build tag string\n  2169const char* getBuildTagString();\n  2170\n  2171struct TypeCheckingCache;\n  2172\n  2173struct ContainerTypeKey\n  2174{\n  2175    slang::TypeReflection* elementType;\n  2176    slang::ContainerType containerType;\n  2177    bool operator==(ContainerTypeKey other) const\n  2178    {\n  2179        return elementType == other.elementType && containerType == other.containerType;\n  2180    }\n  2181    Slang::HashCode getHashCode() const\n  2182    {\n  2183        return Slang::combineHash(\n  2184            Slang::getHashCode(elementType),\n  2185            Slang::getHashCode(containerType));\n  2186    }\n  2187};\n  2188\n  2189/// A dictionary of modules to be considered when resolving `import`s,\n  2190/// beyond those that would normally be found through a `Linkage`.\n  2191///\n  2192/// Checking of an `import` declaration will bottleneck through\n  2193/// `Linkage::findOrImportModule`, which would usually just check for\n  2194/// any module that had been previously loaded into the same `Linkage`\n  2195/// (e.g., by a call to `Linkage::loadModule()`).\n  2196///\n  2197/// In the case where compilation is being done through an\n  2198/// explicit `FrontEndCompileRequest` or `EndToEndCompileRequest`,\n  2199/// the modules being compiled by that request do not get added to\n  2200/// the surrounding `Linkage`.\n  2201///\n  2202/// There is a corner case when an explicit compile request has\n  2203/// multiple `TranslationUnitRequest`s, because the user (reasonably)\n  2204/// expects that if they compile `A.slang` and `B.slang` as two\n  2205/// distinct translation units in the same compile request, then\n  2206/// an `import B` inside of `A.slang` should resolve to reference\n  2207/// the code of `B.slang`. But because neither `A` nor `B` gets\n  2208/// added to the `Linkage`, and the `Linkage` is what usually\n  2209/// determines what is or isn't loaded, that intuition will\n  2210/// be wrong, without a bit of help.\n  2211///\n  2212/// The `LoadedModuleDictionary` is thus filled in by a\n  2213/// `FrontEndCompileRequest` to collect the modules it is compiling,\n  2214/// so that they can cross-reference one another (albeit with\n  2215/// a current implementation restriction that modules in the\n  2216/// request can only `import` those earlier in the request...).\n  2217///\n  2218/// The dictionary then gets passed around between nearly all of\n  2219/// the operations that deal with loading modules, to make sure\n  2220/// that they can detect a previously loaded module.\n  2221///\n  2222typedef Dictionary<Name*, Module*> LoadedModuleDictionary;\n  2223\n  2224enum ModuleBlobType\n  2225{\n  2226    Source,\n  2227    IR\n  2228};\n  2229\n  2230/// A context for loading and re-using code modules.\n  2231class Linkage : public RefObject, public slang::ISession\n  2232{\n  2233public:\n  2234    SLANG_REF_OBJECT_IUNKNOWN_ALL\n  2235\n  2236 2772\n  2773/// A visitor for use with `ComponentType`s, allowing dispatch over the concrete subclasses.\n  2774class ComponentTypeVisitor\n  2775{\n  2776public:\n  2777    // The following methods should be overriden in a concrete subclass\n  2778    // to customize how it acts on each of the concrete types of component.\n  2779    //\n  2780    // In cases where the application wants to simply \"recurse\" on a\n  2781    // composite, specialized, or legacy component type it can use\n  2782    // the `visitChildren` methods below.\n  2783    //\n  2784    virtual void visitEntryPoint(\n  2785        EntryPoint* entryPoint,\n  2786        EntryPoint::EntryPointSpecializationInfo* specializationInfo) = 0;\n  2787    virtual void visitModule(\n  2788        Module* module,\n  2789        Module::ModuleSpecializationInfo* specializationInfo) = 0;\n  2790    virtual void visitComposite(\n  2791        CompositeComponentType* composite,\n  2792        CompositeComponentType::CompositeSpecializationInfo* specializationInfo) = 0;\n  2793    virtual void visitSpecialized(SpecializedComponentType* specialized) = 0;\n  2794    virtual void visitTypeConformance(TypeConformance* conformance) = 0;\n  2795    virtual void visitRenamedEntryPoint(\n  2796        RenamedEntryPointComponentType* renamedEntryPoint,\n  2797        EntryPoint::EntryPointSpecializationInfo* specializationInfo) = 0;\n  2798\n  2799protected:\n  2800    // These helpers can be used to recurse into the logical children of a\n  2801    // component type, and are useful for the common case where a visitor\n  2802    // only cares about a few leaf cases.\n  2803    //\n  2804    void visitChildren(\n  2805        CompositeComponentType* composite,\n  2806        CompositeComponentType::CompositeSpecializationInfo* specializationInfo);\n  2807    void visitChildren(SpecializedComponentType* specialized);\n  2808};\n  2809\n  2810/// A `TargetProgram` represents a `ComponentType` specialized for a particular `TargetRequest`\n  2811///\n  2812/// TODO: This should probably be renamed to `TargetComponentType`.\n  2813///\n  2814/// By binding a component type to a specific target, a `TargetProgram` allows\n  2815/// for things like layout to be computed, that fundamentally depend on\n  2816/// the choice of target.\n  2817///\n  2818/// A `TargetProgram` handles request for compiled kernel code for\n  2819/// entry point functions. In practice, kernel code can only be\n  2820/// correctly generated when the underlying `ComponentType` is \"fully linked\"\n  2821/// (has no remaining unsatisfied requirements).\n  2822///\n  2823class TargetProgram : public RefObject\n  2824{\n  2825public:\n  2826    TargetProgram(ComponentType* componentType, TargetRequest* targetReq);\n  2827\n  2828    /// Get the underlying program\n  2829    ComponentType* getProgram() { return m_program; }\n  2830\n  2831    /// Get the underlying target\n  2832    TargetRequest* getTargetReq() { return m_targetReq; }\n  2833\n  2834    /// Get the layout for the program on the target.\n  2835    ///\n  2836    /// If this is the first time the layout has been\n  2837    /// requested, report any errors that arise during\n  2838    /// layout to the given `sink`.\n  2839    ///\n  2840    ProgramLayout* getOrCreateLayout(DiagnosticSink* sink);\n  2841\n  2842    /// Get the layout for the program on the target.\n  2843    ///\n  2844    /// This routine assumes that `getOrCreateLayout`\n  2845    /// has already been called previously.\n  2846    ///\n  2847    ProgramLayout* getExistingLayout()\n  2848    {\n  2849        SLANG_ASSERT(m_layout);\n  2850        return m_layout;\n  2851    }\n  2852\n  2853    /// Get the compiled code for an entry point on the target.\n  2854    ///\n  2855    /// If this is the first time that code generation has\n  2856    /// been requested, report any errors that arise during\n  2857    /// code generation to the given `sink`.\n  2858    ///\n  2859    IArtifact* getOrCreateEntryPointResult(Int entryPointIndex, DiagnosticSink* sink);\n  2860    IArtifact* getOrCreateWholeProgramResult(DiagnosticSink* sink);\n  2861\n  2862    IArtifact* getExistingWholeProgramResult() { return m_wholeProgramResult; }\n  2863    /// Get the compiled code for an entry point on the target.\n  2864    ///\n  2865    /// This routine assumes that `getOrCreateEntryPointResult`\n  2866    /// has already been called previously.\n  2867    ///\n  2868    IArtifact* getExistingEntryPointResult(Int entryPointIndex)\n  2869    {\n  2870        return m_entryPointResults[entryPointIndex];\n  2871    }\n  2872\n  2873    IArtifact* _createWholeProgramResult(\n  2874        DiagnosticSink* sink,\n  2875        EndToEndCompileRequest* endToEndReq = nullptr);\n  2876\n  2877    /// Internal helper for `getOrCreateEntryPointResult`.\n  2878    ///\n  2879    /// This is used so that command-line and API-based\n  2880    /// requests for code can bottleneck through the same place.\n  2881    ///\n  2882    /// Shouldn't be called directly by most code.\n  2883    ///\n  2884    IArtifact* _createEntryPointResult(\n  2885        Int entryPointIndex,\n  2886        DiagnosticSink* sink,\n  2887        EndToEndCompileRequest* endToEndReq = nullptr);\n  2888\n  2889    RefPtr<IRModule> getOrCreateIRModuleForLayout(DiagnosticSink* sink);\n  2890\n  2891    RefPtr<IRModule> getExistingIRModuleForLayout() { return m_irModuleForLayout; All optional capabilities need to be enumerated as part of the `CapabilitySet`\n  2937    //  system, so that they can be reasoned about uniformly across different targets\n  2938    //  and different layers of the compiler.\n  2939    //\n  2940    // 2. The front-end should be responsible for either or both of:\n  2941    //\n  2942    //   * Checking that `public` or otherwise externally-visible items (declarations/definitions)\n  2943    //     explicitly declare the capabilities they require, and that they only ever\n  2944    //     make use of items that are comatible with those required capabilities.\n  2945    //\n  2946    //   * Inferring the capabilities required by items that are not externally visible,\n  2947    //     and attaching those capabilities explicit as a modifier or other synthesized AST node.\n  2948    //\n  2949    // 3. The capabilities required by a given `ComponentType` and its entry points should be\n  2950    // explicitly know-able, and they should be something we can compare to the capabilities\n  2951    // of a code generation target *before* back-end code generation is started. We should be\n  2952    // able to issue error messages around lacking capabilities in a way the user can understand,\n  2953    // in terms of the high-level-language entities.\n  2954\n  2955public:\n  2956};\n  2957\n  2958struct RequiredLoweringPassSet\n  2959{\n  2960    bool debugInfo;\n  2961    bool resultType;\n  2962    bool optionalType;\n  2963    bool enumType;\n  2964 bitcast;\n  2971    bool existentialTypeLayout;\n  2972    bool bindingQuery;\n  2973    bool meshOutput;\n  2974    bool higherOrderFunc;\n  2975    bool globalVaryingVar;\n  2976    bool glslSSBO;\n missingReturn;\n  2983    bool nonVectorCompositeSelect;\n  2984};\n  2985\n  2986/// A context for code generation in the compiler back-end\n  2987struct CodeGenContext\n  2988{\n  2989public:\n 3117protected:\n  3118    CodeGenTarget m_targetFormat = CodeGenTarget::Unknown;\n  3119    Profile m_targetProfile;\n  3120    ExtensionTracker* m_extensionTracker = nullptr;\n  3121\n  3122    // To improve the performance of our backend, we will try to avoid running\n  3123    // passes related to features not used in the user code.\n  3124    // To do so, we will scan the IR module once, and determine which passes are needed\n  3125    // based on the instructions used in the IR module.\n  3126    // This will allow us to skip running passes that are not needed, without having to\n  3127    // run all the passes only to find out that no work is needed.\n  3128    // This is especially important for the performance of the backend, as some passes\n  3129    // have an initialization cost (such as building reference graphs or DOM trees) that\n  3130    // can be expensive.\n  3131    RequiredLoweringPassSet m_requiredLoweringPassSet;\n  3132\n  3133    /// Will output assembly as well 3560    SLANG_FORCE_INLINE static const BaseTypeInfo& getInfo(BaseType baseType)\n  3561    {\n  3562        return s_info[Index(baseType)];\n  3563    }\n  3564\n  3565    static UnownedStringSlice 3573private:\n  3574    static const BaseTypeInfo s_info[Index(BaseType::CountOf)];\n  3575};\n  3576\n  3577class CodeGenTransitionMap\n  3578{\n  3579public:\n  3580    struct Pair\n  3581    {\n  3582        typedef Pair ThisType;\n  3583        SLANG_FORCE_INLINE bool operator==(const ThisType& rhs) const\n  3584        {\n  3585            return source == rhs.source && target == rhs.target;\n  3586        }\n  3587        SLANG_FORCE_INLINE bool operator!=(const ThisType& rhs) const { return !(*this == rhs); }\n  3588\n  3589        SLANG_FORCE_INLINE HashCode getHashCode() const\n  3590        {\n  3591            return combineHash(HashCode(source), HashCode(target));\n  3592        }\n  3593\n  3594        CodeGenTarget source;\n  3595        CodeGenTarget target;\n  3596    };\n  3597\n  3598    void removeTransition(CodeGenTarget source, CodeGenTarget target)\n  3599    {\n  3600        m_map.remove(Pair{source, target});\n  3601    }\n  3602    void addTransition(CodeGenTarget source, CodeGenTarget target, PassThroughMode compiler)\n  3603    {\n  3604        SLANG_ASSERT(source != target);\n  3605        m_map.set(Pair{source, target}, compiler);\n  3606    }\n  3607    bool hasTransition(CodeGenTarget source, CodeGenTarget target) const\n  3608    {\n  3609        return m_map.containsKey(Pair{source, target});\n  3610    }\n  3611    PassThroughMode getTransition(CodeGenTarget source, CodeGenTarget target) const\n  3612    {\n  3613        const Pair pair{source, target};\n  3614        auto value = m_map.tryGetValue(pair);\n  3615        return value ? *value : PassThroughMode::None;\n  3616    }\n  3617\n  3618protected:\n  3619    Dictionary<Pair, PassThroughMode> m_map;\n  3620};\n  3621\n  3622class GlobalSession : outDiagnostics = nullptr) SLANG_OVERRIDE;\n   394\n   395    CompilerOptionSet& getOptionSet() { return m_optionSet; }\n   396\n   397    /// Get the linkage (aka \"session\" in the public API) for this component type.\n   398    Linkage* getLinkage() { return m_linkage; }\n   399\n   400    /// Get the target-specific version of this program for the given `target`.\n   401    ///\n   402    /// The `target` must be a target on the `Linkage` that was used to create this program.\n   403    TargetProgram* getTargetProgram(TargetRequest* target);\n   404\n   405    /// Update the hash builder with the dependencies for this component type.\n   406    virtual void buildHash(DigestBuilder<SHA1>& builder) = 0;\n   407\n   408    /// Get the number of entry points linked into this component index) = 0;\n   413\n   414    /// Get the mangled name of one of the entry points linked into this component type.\n   415    virtual String getEntryPointMangledName(Index index) = 0;\n   416\n   417 getSpecializationParam(Index index) = 0;\n   428\n   429    /// Get the number of \"requirements\" that this component type has.\n   430    ///\n   431    /// A requirement represents another component type that this component\n   432    /// needs in order to function correctly. For example, the dependency\n   433    /// of one module on another module that it `import`s is represented\n   434    /// as a requirement, as is the dependency of an entry point on the\n   435    /// module that defines it.\n   436    ///\n   437    virtual Index getRequirementCount() = 0;\n   438\n   439    /// Get the requirement at `index`.\n   440    virtual RefPtr<ComponentType> getRequirement(Index index) = 0;\n   441\n   442    /// Parse a type from a string, in the context of this component type.\n   443    ///\n   444    /// Any names in the string will be resolved using 450    /// TODO: This function shouldn't be on the base class, since\n   451    /// it only really makes sense on `Module`.\n   452    ///\n   453    Type* getTypeFromString(String const& typeStr,
